testaments.name: Old Testament
testaments.description: The first part of the Christian Bible, comprising ancient Hebrew scriptures. It consists of narratives, laws, poetry, and prophecies, traditionally attributed to authors from 1200-165 BCE. The Old Testament contains 39 books in Protestant canons, and additional texts in Catholic and Orthodox traditions.

testaments.name: New Testament
testaments.description: The second division of the Christian biblical canon, containing 27 books that describe the life and teachings of Jesus, the early Christian church, and Christian theology. Written primarily in Koine Greek during the first century CE, it includes four Gospels, Acts of the Apostles, 21 Epistles, and the Book of Revelation.

testaments.name: Apocrypha
testaments.description: A collection of ancient religious texts found in some editions of the Bible but excluded from others. These works, which include books like Tobit, Judith, Wisdom of Solomon, and Maccabees, are canonical in Catholic and Orthodox traditions but considered non-canonical in Protestant denominations. Most were composed between 300 BCE and 100 CE.
